title: 2018 Lore Tournament!  (Vote for your favorite stories of the year)

replies.body:
This is such a neat idea!!!

*So* ready for the rest of the tourney, although it seems my pick is losing so far for this round :(

> [{quoted}](name=KnightsKemplar,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-12-06T21:44:29.165+0000)
>
> This is such a neat idea!!!
> 
> *So* ready for the rest of the tourney, although it seems my pick is losing so far for this round :(

The day is young.  Maybe you could make a compelling argument for your pick and sway the masses? :D

Ezreal is way more badass than he gets credit for. His self-reporting obviously makes it all sound more routine than it actually is, in a vain attempt to make himself look better, but that's part of why the story is so fun. He's a hero with realistic flaws, and I find that compelling. 

Perhaps it's because I'm ensconced in academia... but I know people who *must* have an internal monologue like this. And it's hilarious to see it written out. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised to hear that the writers were inspired by real-life stories about academics; his obsession with pleasing the faceless "Explorer's Guild" is such an obvious parallel with pleasing one's academic colleagues.

Actually, in writing this out, I'm seeing why maybe this story doesn't appeal to a large swath of League's fanbase :P But nevertheless, the people responsible for that character and story should be proud. You captured something real there, and I appreciate it very much. Ezreal, as a character, speaks to my life experience.

With all due respect, I disagree completely. And it has nothing to do with the fact that it is couched in a broader context of academic institutions and how they function. There are two main things I strongly dislike about it:

Ezreal is an arrogant snob. From reading some of his other lore, I get the impression that he is actually a somewhat accomplished explorer, but this particular story depicts him as someone who clearly has no idea what he's doing (he brought no food with him?!), yet presses on ahead recklessly anyway, destroys ancient artifacts (the door) that could have contained very valuable information, and after unleashing mayhem on the city, has the gall to place 100% of the blame on everyone but himself. All in the pursuit for his own personal glory, which is clearly the only thing that even remotely matters to him. Not preserving history. Not finding answers. Certainly not the lives of other people. Just himself. If this story accurately represents Ezreal's character, then I can't consider him a hero at all. I find his flaws 'realistic' in the sense that yes, some people are narcissistic and short-sighted, and none of those things are good.

My second problem is fairly simple: plot armor. Ezreal shows up woefully unprepared, and actually stumbles upon some things that sound like they have some real power. Despite this seeming imbalance, there is absolutely no indication that Ezreal was ever in any real trouble. It makes the story completely zero-stakes, as Ezreal doesn't need to utilize his skill, determination, intelligence, or any other potential factors to survive. He just gets to because dumb-luck-plot-armor. Now I realize that this may partly be because it is written as though from his perspective, and he may have rather selectively left a few things out. That then just goes back to my first point. Why do I want to read something that just serves as an ego trip for the 'writer' (not the real author of course)? Well, I don't.

> [{quoted}](name=Elf0491,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=0002000000000000,timestamp=2018-12-06T23:10:08.840+0000)
>
> With all due respect, I disagree completely. And it has nothing to do with the fact that it is couched in a broader context of academic institutions and how they function. There are two main things I strongly dislike about it:
> 
> Ezreal is an arrogant snob. From reading some of his other lore, I get the impression that he is actually a somewhat accomplished explorer, but this particular story depicts him as someone who clearly has no idea what he's doing (he brought no food with him?!), yet presses on ahead recklessly anyway, destroys ancient artifacts (the door) that could have contained very valuable information, and after unleashing mayhem on the city, has the gall to place 100% of the blame on everyone but himself. All in the pursuit for his own personal glory, which is clearly the only thing that even remotely matters to him. Not preserving history. Not finding answers. Certainly not the lives of other people. Just himself. If this story accurately represents Ezreal's character, then I can't consider him a hero at all. I find his flaws 'realistic' in the sense that yes, some people are narcissistic and short-sighted, and none of those things are good.
> 

Well those are his flaws. I don't mind either of them. Plus he is an explorer, not an archaeologist. So perhaps the history of the locations he visits isn't his top priority. 

> My second problem is fairly simple: plot armor. Ezreal shows up woefully unprepared, and actually stumbles upon some things that sound like they have some real power. Despite this seeming imbalance, there is absolutely no indication that Ezreal was ever in any real trouble. It makes the story completely zero-stakes, as Ezreal doesn't need to utilize his skill, determination, intelligence, or any other potential factors to survive. He just gets to because dumb-luck-plot-armor. Now I realize that this may partly be because it is written as though from his perspective, and he may have rather selectively left a few things out. That then just goes back to my first point. Why do I want to read something that just serves as an ego trip for the 'writer' (not the real author of course)? Well, I don't.

I figure he's more of 'holistic' explorer. : D

It's a short story, the scope was limited. Though I do feel there could have been more details. It would have lent a bit more credibility to his account.

honestly that's kinda the point, ezreal plays everything by ear and skates by on talent 

I didn't really like this story either but your criticisms kinda seem like you missed the whole point of it

I do think they go way too hard on snobbiness though. We get it, he's arrogant, but it's cartoonish

I agree that this is in character for him but it's hard to like a character that plays so far into his flaws and irreverence lol. There wasn't much subtlety in that story. I did like his other story a lot, where he's talking to the cultist and haggling, and his other story where he's cave diving for that vial or whatever it was. It's just the journal that seemed off; he was written to be a pompous idiot after a getrichquick scheme instead of somebody who powers through stuff with his mentality.

I feel like he is ready to be a good character and have depth, but we haven't seen much of it yet. I'm ready for it, but it had better happen when or before he meets Lux (which seems inevitable). Her situation has gotten very somber in contrast with her character and I love it.
Waiting to vote for Eye in the Abyss, that story was flawless, and instilled in me a great desire for a new champ that comes from those ranks of Lissandra's soldiers.
It might still be my favorite story

> [{quoted}](name=Bioluminescence,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=,timestamp=2018-12-06T21:26:00.008+0000)

>no skin-universe

*sobs in cowboy*

Look, Jared - we've been over this. If you NEVER sleep at all, you can also fit in some Runeterra-based stories as well...

{{sticker:vlad-salute}}

> [{quoted}](name=Carnival Knights,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=000c,timestamp=2018-12-06T22:29:08.216+0000)
>
> *sobs in cowboy*

How else am I going to ~~chea~~ legitimately have some of these main-universe stories have a chance if Odyssey, Star Guardian, and High Noon, are competing??  (Also, I'd run out of days of the year.)

Is it possible to have a separate Skin-universe story competition as well? :D we have many amazing alternative universes.

i really like this idea by the way.

Frozen Hearts was really cute and a great way to show off Nunu's character and his relationship with his mom. However I feel like it was just kind of...there. Nothing really interesting happened other than Nunu's mom telling him small stories and how the Notai live and stuff.

"An Explorer's Journey" however confirmed a sudden revelation that Zaun was originally a Shuriman settlement and that there is a huge catacomb of Shuriman treasures in the deepest, darkest parts of the city. The story itself was also a hell of a lot more entertaining and exciting, coupled with some nice pieces of art too!

All in all, my vote is Explorer's Journey.

> [{quoted}](name=BonzaiBuddy,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=0007,timestamp=2018-12-06T21:54:36.588+0000)
>
> Frozen Hearts was really cute and a great way to show off Nunu's character and his relationship with his mom. However I feel like it was just kind of...there. Nothing really interesting happened other than Nunu's mom telling him small stories and how the Notai live and stuff.
> 
> "An Explorer's Journey" however confirmed a sudden revelation that Zaun was originally a Shuriman settlement and that there is a huge catacomb of Shuriman treasures in the deepest, darkest parts of the city. The story itself was also a hell of a lot more entertaining and exciting, coupled with some nice pieces of art too!
> 
> All in all, my vote is Explorer's Journey.

That's a good call on the Zaun revelation.  I hadn't considered that, and I really love juicy worldbuilding factoids.  Hrm.
For me, that makes it feel worse that Ezreal doesn't really seem to care about any of it in the journal, since Shurima fans were really interested.
Ooh, some of these match ups are really gonna be tough to decide. Specifically looking at {{champion:555}} vs {{champion:45}} and {{champion:266}} vs {{champion:56}} .

Gah you paired Nunu's story with his mom with my Freelo Explorer's expedition?  How am I supposed to pick?!?

Probably gotta stick with my fav champion, but I love both of them.

This is a hard one, both of the stories are pretty darn good, having character displayed in each of them and being written in an overall great way! I'm going to have to give my vote to An Explorer's Journey, from a matter of me just liking explorers. Both of them are most definitely amazing though!

I was about to make a strong case for what the top 4 stories should be, but then I realized I have a second top 4 that could easily tie the first top 4 I thought of originally. How can you expect us to vote in the later rounds if you make too many good stories?

> [{quoted}](name=Naalith,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Wns6RG83,comment-id=0010,timestamp=2018-12-07T01:06:57.484+0000)
>
> I was about to make a strong case for what the top 4 stories should be, but then I realized I have a second top 4 that could easily tie the first top 4 I thought of originally. How can you expect us to vote in the later rounds if you make too many good stories?

Why do you think I made this in the first place?  I need all of your help deciding - because I certainly can't.
Can we skip to The Principles of Strength, the clearly superior story.
Frozen Hearts is better imo, i really liked the relationship between Nunu and his mother
Nunu > Ez
Frozen Hearts, no doubt.  Not a fan of a story where one of my first and favorite champions turned out to be a scum-bro.
We can't vote for those pre-retcon. Well, waste of time for me, then.

This is my first time reading both stories and my vote goes to Frozen Heart's. Both were well written and I enjoyed both immensely though I did feel somewhat overwhelmed as my lore knowledge is still sub par.

I think Frozen Heart's had a more concise and complete concept to the story and the story telling aspect reminded me alot of other fantasy novels I read while younger. The setting is also much more suited to December so couldnt help but relate to it. Nunu's character also really matched his in game personality which was another positive. Similarly Ezreals story but I haven't played as much of him since his rework as I have nunu.

As for Ezreals story I felt it could have been fleshed out a bit more. The personality and humour were there but the exploration aspect didn't quite hit the mark. I would have liked more details with regards to the place he was exploring, the challenges he faced and major successes. The diary format was fun and very appropriate plus the first person account was refreshing but it also felt a bit disjointed. Both geographically and timewise.
I just want to say Principles of Strenght and From the Ashes were the two best stories of the year for me. Those two deserve to go far in this tournament imo.
Voting for my boy Matt Dunn this round
